Step 1 – Analyzing the Situation:
• My outside offer guarantees me a value of 313.
• The item details are:
 – Item 1: 3 units at a value of 23 each (total 69 if I get all)
 – Item 2: 2 units at 94 each (total 188)
 – Item 3: 2 units at 65 each (total 130)
 – Item 4: 3 units at 65 each (total 195)
 – Item 5: 7 units at 14 each (total 98)
 The full “pie” is worth 680 to me.
• In round 1 the discount factor is gamma^(0)=1, so any deal now is undiscunted.
• I must propose an offer that, if accepted, gives me at least 313 in value, while trying to maximize my share.

Step 2 – Assessing Offer Values:
• When making a counteroffer, I propose a split by specifying what I give to Player 2. I then receive the leftover items.
• Since my highest valued items (by unit) are items 2, 3, and 4 (values 94, 65, and 65), I want to retain these.
• Items with lower unit value for me (items 1 at 23 and item 5 at 14) are more “expendable.” 
• One aggressive strategy is to give Player 2 all the units of items that I value less. In doing so I keep items 2, 3, and 4.
• For example, if I offer Player 2 all of item 1 (3 units) and all of item 5 (7 units), my kept share is:
  - Item 2: 2 units (value = 2 × 94 = 188)
  - Item 3: 2 units (value = 2 × 65 = 130)
  - Item 4: 3 units (value = 3 × 65 = 195)
 Total value = 188 + 130 + 195 = 513, which is well above my outside offer (513 > 313).
• This counteroffer avoids the mistakes:
 – I’m not proposing an outcome below my fallback.
 – I’m not giving away everything, and I’m keeping all high‐value items.
 – Though aggressive, it is a valid strategic opening for round 1.

Step 3 – Decision and Final Offer:
• Given that my kept-share would be 513, this offer is beneficial if accepted.
• My action is to propose the counteroffer where Player 2 receives all 3 units of item 1 and all 7 units of item 5, and I retain the remaining items.

My analysis is as follows:

• My guaranteed fallback (outside offer) guarantees a value of 560. In any division I propose, the portion I keep must sum (using my private per‐unit values) to more than 560 so that I do not “sell myself short.”

• There are 5 item types with total quantities [4, 3, 6, 5, 5] and my per-unit values are [47, 22, 51, 35, 61] respectively. If I were to keep all items I would realize 1040 in value. In a fair split (roughly 50–50) I would only get about 520, which is less than my outside offer. So I need to “hog” slightly more than half the value. In effect, I must design my division so that the items I keep evaluated at my private numbers sum to at least 560.

• I also want to leave the opponent with something reasonable so they have an incentive to accept. I can concede more of those items that are relatively less valuable to me. For example, item 2 is only 22 per unit, so I can concede more units there. Meanwhile, I want to keep more of the high‐value items (like items 3 and 5). At the same time I want to avoid offering nothing to the opponent on any item (to avoid the “offering nothing” mistake).

• One possible proposal is to offer to the opponent the following units on each item:
  – Item 1: give 1 unit (keep 3, value = 3×47 = 141)
  – Item 2: give 2 units (keep 1, value = 1×22 = 22)
  – Item 3: give 2 units (keep 4, value = 4×51 = 204)
  – Item 4: give 2 units (keep 3, value = 3×35 = 105)
  – Item 5: give 2 units (keep 3, value = 3×61 = 183)

• Adding up my kept share gives: 141 + 22 + 204 + 105 + 183 = 655. This is safely above my fallback of 560. In addition, the offer gives the opponent nonzero amounts in every item, avoiding unilateral concessions that might trigger a rejection.

Thus, in the first round my action will be to propose this counteroffer:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 2, 2, 2, 2]}

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [3, 3, 4, 4, 5] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:
    61 x 3 + 81 x 3 + 20 x 4 + 74 x 4 + 89 x 5
    which is 1247 (sum of all item values) 
    
    which is less than your outside offer of 1252. If your proposed offer results in a value lower than your outside offer, continue iterating until you develop a more advantageous offer that is better than your outside offer. 
    This reasoning can be applied to each of the five highlighted mistakes to ensure that your offers align with your objectives and avoid undesirable negotiation behaviors.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [0, 2, 0, 0, 1] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:
    78 x 0 + 47 x 2 + 12 x 0 + 81 x 0 + 35 x 1
    which is 129 (sum of all item values) 
    
    which is less than your outside offer of 131. If your proposed offer results in a value lower than your outside offer, continue iterating until you develop a more advantageous offer that is better than your outside offer.
